Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Alice DPoW adds checkpoints dynamically at runtime

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: Okay I leave dPoW answers to this master üôÇ

Author: Alice#9607
Content: @dukeleto thanks

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Alice a block becomes a dynamic checkpoint when it has been "notarized", i.e. it's block hash data has been sent to KMD and eventually BTC

Author: Alice#9607
Content: its like the peercoin checkpointing system

Author: Alice#9607
Content: I guess

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Not familiar with peercoin stuff, but maybe üòÉ

Author: Alice#9607
Content: I did some checkpointing implementations

Author: Alice#9607
Content: the notarisation nodes are the checkpointing masters?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content:
`getinfo` on a coin protected by DPoW will have something like this: ```  "notarizedhash": "0000000922916773217667e205ff9925bb4c16cba70754acdf3a8354ce194874",
  "notarizedtxid": "9d162c25076291e35aa2b2bff7f265d79f2bd2b94e3344afc52c357f4cb9b4a7",
  "notarized": 398882```

Author: Alice#9607
Content: the problem with checkpointing is the centralization

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Alice kmd notary nodes come together and need to agree on what the data should be, that data is injected into the blockchain via a transaction (13 vins, 2 vouts) with OP_RETURN data, then normal nodes can grab notarization data from those xtns

Author: Alice#9607
Content: ok, similar to EOS system then?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: we have 64 notary nodes that are community elected, half go up for re-election each year and the top-half, by stats, stay

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I help run this notary node, for instance: https://komodostats.com/node.php?id=16

Author: Alice#9607
Content: does it cost KMD to run a notary node?

Author: Alice#9607
Content: Can I add one of my servers?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: no, you get KMD for running a notary node

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: 75% of KMD block reward goes to notary nodes, 25% to other miners

Author: Alice#9607
Content: I have to be elected I guess

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: elections are Q1 each year, and they switch over around Q2

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: this is another cool site that shows notarization data across all coins: http://notarystats.com/

Author: Alice#9607
Content: If I want to contribute a server, how do I get started?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: "lag" is the difference between the latest block and the last notarized block. It's an upper bound on re-org size, there can never be a re-org greater than lag, by consensus rules

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Alice what exactly do you want to do?

Author: Alice#9607
Content: run a notary node

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: https://github.com/chainstrike/nntools/tree/master/guides

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: those guides will show you what is involved, it's a lot of work, we are constantly adding coins

Author: Alice#9607
Content: I have been running crypto infrastructure nodes for quite some time

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: well that will help a lot

Author: Alice#9607
Content: amazon servers

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: we have about 40 coin daemons in additions to BTC, and then a few other crazy servers

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: "iguana" is the software that performs notarizations

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: https://github.com/jl777/SuperNET/tree/master/iguana

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: imagine it as a glue API that talks to all the coin daemons on localhost and then does crazy cross-chain magic with them

Author: Alice#9607
Content: how much ram and ssd space?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: we had recommendations for this year, i forget what they were. More RAM is better, and at least 500GB space

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content:
```A good CPU (e.g. Xeon or i7)
At least 64GB of RAM
At least 500GB SSD of disk space
Fast uplink of at least 100Mbps and very strong network connectivity```

Author: Alice#9607
Content: so you run the coin daemons that are getting notarised locally?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: from here: https://komodoplatform.com/2018-notary-node-elections/

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: yes, every notary node runs a full node of every coin daemon

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: notary nodes make transactions on many chains, constantly, injecting dpow data via OP_RETURN

Author: Alice#9607
Content: I see

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: average nodes then read that data and populate their notarization DB

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and everyone has consensus rules regarding these notarized checkpoints, they cannot be re-org'ed

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: for next year, I would double the HD requirement to 1TB, we are adding coins like crazy

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: most NN's dont' use AWS because it's too expensive, especially bandwidth

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: NN's use a lot of bandwidth

Author: Alice#9607
Content: that size of machine costs some money

Author: Alice#9607
Content: true

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: dedicated physical boxen

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: 64 of them

Author: Alice#9607
Content: how much KMD do you get to cover the cost?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: So notary nodes get to mine with difficulty=1 when it's their "turn", so you basically mine a lot of KMD as a notary node

Author: Alice#9607
Content: cpu mining that is?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: each of the 64 nodes gets a fair share, and yes, it's CPU mining

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the pubkeys of the 64 notary nodes are embedded in the source code

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: something around 1200KMD per month per notary node, but it can vary. You can hit a "big block" of some place that doesn't implement interest, and get a massive bonus

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: somebody just got 17000 KMD I think. Mining KMD has a bit of a bonus lottery, some blocks are bigger because some places don't implement interest

Author: Alice#9607
Content: you can by a server for that

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and the difference in the sum of inputs and output goes to the happy miner üòÉ

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i have seen 20,000 KMD and bigger bonuses, it's quite the lottery

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: "i have seen" others get it, largest I have gotten is 13 KMD üòπ

Author: Alice#9607
Content: üò©

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: anyway, NN running is very fun, very educational, very time consuming

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and I love it and the people I get to work with are some of the best
